alternative.title: Alternative
alternative.text: An alternative is one of the different options for treatment/intervention being explored in a benefit-risk analysis, e.g. "aspirin 40 mg/day" or "meditation therapy".

alternatives-per-rank.title: Alternatives per rank
alternatives-per-rank.text: How likely each alterntive is to have a specific rank (with 1 being best) overall.

central-weights.title: Central weights
central-weights.text: The central weight for each alternative, per criterion.

configured-range.title: Configured range
configured-range.text: Which range the user has actually configured to be used. Without user intervention the default scales are the observed ranges.

criterion.title: Criterion
criterion.text: A criterion is an outcome of interest to be used in a benefit-risk analysis, e.g. "mood improvement" or "nausea".

criterion-data-source.title: Criterion data source
criterion-data-source.text: Criterion data can be entered as either study data, or an exact-value distribution.

criterion-datatype.title: Criterion data type
criterion-datatype.text: Criterion data can be reported in several ways, either as a proportion (e.g. "fifty out of a hundred"), a continuous value (e.g. "weight increase in grams") or as survival data (e.g. "median survival after 20 days)"

criterion-source.title: Criterion data source
criterion-source.text: An optional indication of where the data for this criterion comes from (single study or meta-analysis)

criterion-source-link.title: Source link
criterion-source-link.text: An optional hyperlink that leads to the source of this criterion's data

criterion-unit.title: Unit of measurement
criterion-unit.text: In which unit of measurement the criterion's data are reported (e.g. "proportion", "gram")

deterministic-analysis-results.title: Deterministic analysis results
deterministic-analysis-results.text: This section shows the results of deterministic analysis (representative weights, total value), allows for sensitivity analysis, and allows modification of the effects table to explore the problem space.

effects-table.title: Effects table
effects-table.text: The effects table shows the size of the effects on each criterion for each alternative. In the case of a known distribution of an effect the values shown are the median value and the 95% credible interval. If the effect is an exact distribution value only that value is shown.

exact-swing.title: Exact SWING weighting
exact-swing.text: Elicitation of the user's exact trade-off weights between the different criteria. This results in exact weight ratios between all the criteria, e.g. increasing effectiveness by 5% is equally desirable to decreasing mortality by 10%.

favorability.title: Favorability
favorability.text: Whether or not an increase in the criterion is seen as favorable.

incomplete-workspaces.title: Incomplete workspaces
incomplete-workspaces.text: The process of manually creating a workspace can be paused at any point. This list shows those unfinished workspaces.

interval-swing.title: Interval SWING weighting
interval-swing.text: Elicitation of the user's  weigh trade-offs between the different criteria, via the interval method. This method allows specification of an interval (rather than an exact value) where changes to two criteria are equivalent. This results in weight ratios between all the criteria, e.g. increasing effectiveness by 5-10% is equally desirable to decreasing mortality by 10-20%.

mcda-input-method.title: Input method
mcda-input-method.text: In mcda, it is possible to input data directly as a distribution of the effects for the treatment for a criterion, or to input the data measured in a study, after which the application will calculate the corresponding distribution automatically.

sensitivity-measurements.title: Measurements sensitivity analysis
sensitivity-measurements.text: How the value of a specific alternative changes as the weight of a specific criterion changes between 0 and 1. All other alternatives' values are kept constant at the current default for comparison.

sensitivity-preferences.title: Preferences sensitivity analysis
sensitivity-preferences.text: How the value of all alternatives changes as the weight of a specific criterion changes between 0 and 1.

observed-range.title: Observed range
observed-range.text: The observed range within which all the effects of a given analysis lie. The lower bound is the lowest among the effects (or of their low end of the 95% CrI in the case of non-exact effect distributions). The upper bound is the maximum of these values.

one-way-sensitivity-analysis.title: One-way sensitivity analysis
one-way-sensitivity-analysis.text: A section that allows exploring of the sensitivity of the results by allowing only one thing to change.

ordinal-swing.title: Ordinal SWING weighting
ordinal-swing.text: Elicitation of the user's ordinal ranking of the weight of the included criteria.

partial-value-function.title: Partial Value Function
partial-value-function.text: A partial value function indicates how the desirability of a criterion's outcome varies with its value.

problem.title: Problem definition
problem.text: The problem definition is a lens through which to view the data for analysis. Criteria and alternatives can be omitted, and scale ranges can be changed.

pvf-type.title: Type of partial value function
pvf-type.text: Partial vlaue functions can be either linear (a straight line between two points) or piece-wise linear, meaning the function consists of several linear segments.

rank-acceptabilities.title: Rank acceptabilities
rank-acceptabilities.text: How likely each intervention is to overall be the best, worst, or any rank in between, based on the SMAA model results for the given preferences and data.

ranks-per-alternative.title: Ranks per alternative
ranks-per-alternative.text: How likely a specific alterntive is to have each rank (with 1 being best) overall.

representative-weights.title: Representative weights
representative-weights.text: Weights representative of how important each criterion is. The total weights add up to one.

scale-ranges.title: Scale ranges
scale-ranges.text: For each criterion there is a theoretical maximum range within which the effects may lie (infinite for continuous criteria, between zero and one), as well as a minimum range (determined by the effects). In most cases only a portion of this range is actually relevant to the data. Here you can adjust these scales to your liking.

scenario.title: Scenario
scenario.text: A scenario is a collection of preferences to feed into the MCDA models. This consists of a partial value function for each criterion, and an optional set of trade-offs (ordinal swing, exact swing or interval swing).

smaa-results.title: SMAA results
smaa-results.text: The results of stochastic multicriteria acceptability analysis (SMAA) for the given preferences.

survival-summary-measure.title: Survival summary measure
survival-summary-measure.text: Which specific aspect of survival is reported, i.e. mean, median, or at a specific moment.

survival-time-point-of-interest.title: Survival summary measure
survival-time-point-of-interest.text: At which specific moment in time the survival data is reported.

survival-time-scale.title: Survival time scale
survival-time-scale.text: On which time scale the survival data are reported.

theoretical-range.title: Theoretical range
theoretical-range.text: The theoretically maximal range in which effect sizes can lie

therapeutic-context.title: Therapeutic context
therapeutic-context.text: Background information about the context in which the data should be interpreted, e.g. information about studies or meta-analyses from which the data comes.

total-value.title: Total value
total-value.text: How valuable (i.e. helpful for each criterion) each alternative is overall.

trade-offs.title: Trade-offs
trade-offs.text: Trade-offs indicate what weight the user places on improving each criterion. First, criteria are ordered by weight of importance, and then the trade-offs can be elicited, i.e. "How much improvement on criterion A would be an equivalent trade-off for some improvement on criterion B?"

treatment.title: Treatment
treatment.text: A treatment is an intervention of interest to be used in a benefit-risk analysis, e.g. "Aspirin 20 mg/day" or "Meditation".

value-profiles.title: Value profiles
value-profiles.text: How the total value of each alternative is composed out of its value for each criterion.

workspace.title: Workspace
workspace.text: A workspace contains your base data, and any definitions you have based thereon, i.e. subselections of criteria and interventions (subproblems) and sets of preferences (scenarios).
